Grace is a split personality now? :sweat_smile:
Yeah why not :)
I have the same for Alan

• Variant A, dynamic languages
  • Variant B, java
the main thing is that the "what does Alan want most" is kind of the same in both cases
and also the "what expectations does alan bring"
I think the same holds for Grace here
at least at some level of detail :)
actually I'm missing a bit about what Grace expects-- I think she's also accustomed to tooling like gdb, perf, or whatever, and would probably like to be able to continue using those tools
(does that sound right?)
pushed a sentence to that effect
I think i'll merge those commits into my main PR
Not sure, I'm definitely not a debugger guy. I'm rather happy that we can do a lot of cool things without having to use those antiquated tools.
maybe it's going a bit far

• Grace is accustomed to various bits of low-level tooling, such as gdb or perf. She would like to be able to use those tools, though she'd be happy to have access to better alternatives if they were available. She's ok using cargo instead of make, for example.
maybe "She would ilke to be able to" is too stron
I feel like I am happy when tools like perf work "reasonably"
but I want improved versions
maybe I'm just writing about me :)
Well, the point is, you can use those tools if you want to (though gdb is a bit iffy with Rust code).

• Grace is accustomed to various bits of low-level tooling, such as gdb or perf. It's nice if Rust works reasonably well with those tools, but she'd be happy to have access to better alternatives if they were available. She's happy using cargo instead of make, for example.
Nice.
i suspect everyone is happy if their existing workflows work, even if they want better ones, just so they can choose when to learn
e.g. I know when I got a windows PC I knew that I ought to learn powershell but I was happy I could just use bash to start :)
(never did learn powershell, but that's neither here nor there)
I'm not sure how far we want to go into the detail wrt the better tooling we have. Some of it is mindboggling and very eye opening.
say more!
i'm not sure I know what you're talking about
Especially when coming from Embedded C/C++ where a lot of things are "special" (and not in a good way) Rust is a true eye opener.
I guess what I mean is, are there special things for embedded you're talking about?
https://probe.rs/
(broke this out into a separate topic)
O_O woah!
I totally think the applications page should have things like this
or a link to where to find things like this
And there're a ton of mind-boggling tools building on probe.rs: cargo-flash, cargo-embed, probe-run...
(cc @pnkfelix, this may be interesting to check out)
We're also using tools like svd2rust to generate Rust abstractions over MMIO register descriptions.
we've been talking a bit about what it would look like to have advanced tooling for debugging and profiling rust applications, esp. (but not limited to) networked services
this is the first time i've heard anyone be positive about the experience of a debugger and Rust :)
maybe just the magic of embedded setting a low bar

The quality of those files provided by the vendors varies quite a bit but at least you can eliminate some of the studying of 2000page manuals quite a bit to figure out which bits to set to achieve something.

Then we have frameworks like RTIC https://rtic.rs/0.5/book/en/ which provides a top shelf concurrency framework to build safe applications with guaranteed hard realtime capabilities, most of which verified and guaranteed at compile time by the Rust compiler.
We may not have much in Rust but what we have is nothing short of a game changer in the industry. ;)
Due to the great FFI capabilities there's also always the possibility to continue using C/C++ code or move to Rust piecemealwise.
(also cc @Carl Lerche, for the same reason)
There're a lot of efforts (outside of the WG realm) which try to leverage that.

Daniel Egger said:

Then we have frameworks like RTIC https://rtic.rs/0.5/book/en/ which provides a top shelf concurrency framework to build safe applications with guaranteed hard realtime capabilities, most of which verified and guaranteed at compile time by the Rust compiler.

another thing I had not seen
